title: Lower-bound of assumed-shape array is lost

labels.name: NEMO
labels.description: Issue relates to the NEMO domain

body:
Simon has reported that when PSyclone processes, e.g.:

    subroutine my_sub(arg)
      implicit none
      real, dimension(2:) :: arg
      arg(:) = 0.0
    end subroutine my_sub

then it loses the lower bound of the array declaration and generates:

    subroutine my_sub(arg)
      real, dimension(:) :: arg
    
      arg(:) = 0.0
    
    end subroutine my_sub

title: Issue with new deallocate statements and reference2arrayreference

labels.name: NEMO
labels.description: Issue relates to the NEMO domain

body:
Many Nemo files now fail to compile after being processed by PSyclone due to expressions like:
`DEALLOCATE(zn0_sto(:), zn_stop(:), zsing(:))`
this is fixed by removing the ranges:
`DEALLOCATE(zn0_sto, zn_stop, zsing)`
This is a combination of PSyclone now supporting DEALLOCATE statements and applying a blanket reference2arrayRange. This second transformation should skip expressions inside certain intrinsic.

title: 1295 fix code execution on import

labels.name: LFRic
labels.description: Issue relates to the LFRic domain

body:
This fixes #1295, code executing when importing a file. The old approach had several problems:
- pylint couldn't verify the attributes and we needed to disable this test
- it is impossible to debug the dynamically created classes
- `exec` is a security risk - our DevOps team has confirmed that any code on our operational machine **will** be scanned, and any `exec` in a python code will be flagged and will require manual approval.
- de-facto a project-specific config files does **not** work, since the `LFRicConstant` class is created before the custom config file is read, making this option useless (and requiring all partner organisations to manually patch their PSyclone installation in order to be able to process LFRic)

This PR fixes this, and it is (esp. because of the last point) essential to be included in the next release, so the LFRic build environment can properly use a project-specific config file (PR for that is on hold because of this bug).

One point worth discussion: I have additionally a small change that would either print a message or raise an exception if an instance of `LFRicConstants` is created before the config file is read. That would protect us against involuntarily re-introducing the problem (e.g. by using the new `LFRicTypes` instance when setting a class variable outside of a function). I am not sure if we all want this strict approach, and if you prefer a message or an exception.

title: Add support for parameter statements
body:
Currently we silently ignore parameter statements e.g.
```
real :: a, b 
parameter (a=1.0, b=2.0)
```
we produce:
```
real :: a
real :: b
```
This can be parsed an add in the constant_value expression:
```
real :: a = 1.0
real :: b = 2.0
```
I have a first implementation of this but there are problems with UnknownTypes.
```
character*5 = hi
parameter (hi='Hello')
```

title: LFRic builtins misses access when field arrays are used
body:
A simple example:
```
  do i=1, 10
    call invoke( a_plus_X(f2(i), a, f1) )
  enddo
```
will not report the access to `f2` or `i`.

The first issue can be fixed using:
```
diff --cc src/psyclone/domain/lfric/lfric_builtins.py
index fea77db71,fea77db71..d62ced014
--- a/src/psyclone/domain/lfric/lfric_builtins.py
+++ b/src/psyclone/domain/lfric/lfric_builtins.py
@@@ -181,7 -181,7 +181,7 @@@ class LFRicBuiltIn(BuiltIn, metaclass=a
          # after all read access (which must happen before something is written)
          written = VariablesAccessInfo()
          for arg in self.args:
--            if arg.form == "variable":
++            if arg.form in ["variable", "indexed_variable"]:
                  if arg.access == AccessType.WRITE:
                      written.add_access(Signature(arg.declaration_name),
                                         arg.access, self)
```
This will now report `f2` in the example above, but the read access to `i` is still missing. It appears that in the `reference_access` function to PSyIR representation of the actual argument is available, only the string `f2(i)`. We can't `lower_to_language_level` easily (if we lower a copy of the builtin, we don't have a scope symbol table, unless we go up the tree to find the scope, duplicate it ... which seems to be a fair amount of effort).

title: Failing test depending on screen width
body:
I have a test failure on master, which turns out to be related to the terminal width:
```
COLUMNS=90 pytest  -k test_main_h_option ./psyad/main_test.py
>       assert expected3 in output
E       AssertionError: assert '  -h, --help            show this help message and exit\n  -a ACTIVE [ACTIVE ...], --active ACTIVE [ACTIVE ...]\n    ...st TEST_FILENAME  filename for the unit test (implies -t)\n  -oad OAD              filename for the transformed code\n' in 'usage: psyad [-h] [-oad OAD] [-v] [-t] [-api API] [-otest TEST_FILENAME] -a ACTIVE [ACTIVE ...] -- filename\n\nRun th...st TEST_FILENAME  filename for the unit test (implies -t)\n  -oad OAD              filename for the transformed code\n'

psyad/main_test.py:136: AssertionError
================================ short test summary info =================================
FAILED psyad/main_test.py::test_main_h_option - AssertionError: assert '  -h, --help   ...
============================ 1 failed, 17 deselected in 0.19s ============================
```
If I use a width of 81 or less, the test passes:
```
COLUMNS=81 pytest  -k test_main_h_option ./psyad/main_test.py 
============================== test session starts ==============================
platform linux -- Python 3.8.10, pytest-6.2.1, py-1.10.0, pluggy-0.13.1
rootdir: /home/joerg/work/psyclone, configfile: setup.cfg
plugins: forked-1.3.0, xdist-2.3.0, cov-2.11.1, anyio-3.5.0
collected 18 items / 17 deselected / 1 selected                                 

psyad/main_test.py .                                                      [100%]

======================= 1 passed, 17 deselected in 0.08s ========================
```

Reason is that the line:
```
  -api API              the PSyclone API that the TL kernel conforms to (if any)
```
which is split before the `any)` if the terminal is too short, but not on my normal terminal width.

Fix:
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/53283297/set-line-length-for-output-in-pythons-argparse

Note that adding a `\n` to the help message did not work.

title: Issues with InliningTrans (with ArraryRef to StructureofArrayRef conversion?)
body:
Trying to inline the call in:
```
     DO j = ssha_t%internal%ystart, ssha_t%internal%ystop, 1
        DO i = ssha_t%internal%xstart, ssha_t%internal%xstop, 1
          CALL continuity_code(i, j, ssha_t%data, sshn_t%data, sshn_u%data, sshn_v%data, hu%data, hv%data, un%data, vn%data, &
&sshn_t%grid%area_t, rdt)
        END DO
      END DO
```
which references the subroutine:
```
SUBROUTINE continuity_code(ji, jj, ssha, sshn, sshn_u, sshn_v, hu, hv, un, vn, e12t, rdt)
  ...
  rtmp1 = (sshn_u(ji,jj) + hu(ji,jj)) * un(ji,jj)
  ...
```

Ends up with:
```
      DO j = ssha_t%internal%ystart, ssha_t%internal%ystop, 1
        DO i = ssha_t%internal%xstart, ssha_t%internal%xstop, 1
          rtmp1 = (sshn_u%data + hu%data) * un%data
          rtmp2 = (sshn_u%data + hu%data) * un%data
          rtmp3 = (sshn_v%data + hv%data) * vn%data
          rtmp4 = (sshn_v%data + hv%data) * vn%data
          ssha_t%data = sshn_t%data + (rtmp2 - rtmp1 + rtmp4 - rtmp3) * rdt / sshn_t%grid%area_t
        END DO
      END DO
```
which misses the array access expressions.

title: [WW3] sub-string of character string causes crash
body:
Asif has reported that the WW3 code uses a character variable:

      CHARACTER(256)          :: LINE, TEST
    100 CONTINUE
      ! read line
      READ ( NDSI, 900, END=800, ERR=801, IOSTAT=IERR, IOMSG=MSG ) LINE
      ! leading blanks removed and placed on the right
      TEST = ADJUSTL ( LINE )
      IF ( TEST(1:1).EQ.CHCKC .OR. LEN_TRIM(TEST).EQ.0 ) THEN

and PSyclone falls over in `ArrayMixin.is_lower_bound` when examinging `TEST(1:1)` because it assumes it is of ArrayType whereas it is in fact of UnknownFortranType (because we don't support Character variables).

    module my_mod

    contains

    subroutine my_sub(iarg)
      write(*,*) iarg

then PSyclone loses the `iarg` argument to the subroutine (presumably because it is never explicitly declared) and the resulting code is wrong.

title: Update fparser version to 0.0.15 in setup.py (for #1748)

labels.name: Release
labels.description: Planning and creating PSyclone releases

body:
As outlined in #1748, when the PSyclone master was updated  to the latest fparser submodule (0.0.15 release) in  #1707, the `setup.py` eas omitted and it still points to fparser 0.0.14 as the prerequisite. When PSyclone and fparser are installed from a working copy of the master by using the fparser from the `external` submodules, fparser 0.0.15 is installed first and from the submodule and then fparser 0.0.14 from the PSyclone's `setup.py`.

I updated the fparser version to 0.0.15 in `setup.py`. I installed PSyclone locally from this branch and can confirm that only fparser 0.0.15 is now installed.

title: Update setup.py to fparser 0.0.15

labels.name: Release
labels.description: Planning and creating PSyclone releases

body:
#1707 updated the PSyclone master to the lastest fparser submodule which is the 0.0.15 release. However, the `setup.py` in PSyclone still points to 0.0.14 as the prerequisite. This affects the installation of PSyclone from a working copy of the master by using the fparser from the `external` submodules. Installing fparser from the submodule downloads and installs 0.0.15 release first and then installs 0.0.14 from the PSyclone's `setup.py`.
I was a code reviewer for #1707 and overlooked this, so I am happy to fix it.

```
-                    mode=AccessType.READ)

         '''Add function-space related arguments common to LMA operators and
```

title: (Closes #1713) Bug fix for 2D matmul
matmul2code transformation produces incorrect code
body:
Embarrassingly, my extension of the matmul2code trans does not produce the correct code for matrix-matrix multiplication.
Currently it gives:

          do j = 1, 3, 1
            do i = 1, 3, 1
              jac(i,j) = 0.0_r_def
              do ii = 1, 3, 1
                jac(i,j) = jac(i,j) + jac_inv(ii,i) * jac_inv_transpose(j,ii)
              enddo
            enddo
          enddo

when it should be:

      jac(i,j) = jac(i,j) + jac_inv(i,ii) * jac_inv_transpose(ii,j)

body:
Example lfric/eg14 shows the problem. What I saw yesterday on a machine with nvidia compiler  for:
```
    call invoke( name = 'Initialise fields',        &
                 setval_c( field1,     0.0_r_def ), &
                 setval_c( field2,     1.0_r_def )  &
                 )
```
was:
```
!$acc& copyin(nlayers,field1_proxy,field1_proxy%data,0.0_r_def,ndf_aspc1_field1,undf_aspc1_field1,map_aspc1_field1,field2_proxy, &
!$acc& field2_proxy%data,1.0_r_def,ndf_aspc1_field2,undf_aspc1_field2,map_aspc1_field2)
      !
      !$acc parallel default(present)
      !$acc loop independent
      DO df=loop0_start,loop0_stop
        field1_proxy%data(df) = 0.0_r_def
      END DO
```
Neither `nlayers`, nor any `(u)def*` values are defined at all (and iirc there were even more variables listed that do not exist).

I just tried to run this again on my machine (no nvfortran, but that shouldn't matter for the psy layer), and now I am getting:
```
!$acc enter data  &
!$acc& copyin(0.0_r_def,1.0_r_def,field1_proxy,field1_proxy%data,field2_proxy,field2_proxy%data,map_aspc1_field1,map_aspc1_field2, &
!$acc& ndf_aspc1_field1,ndf_aspc1_field2,nlayers,undf_aspc1_field1,undf_aspc1_field2)
      !
      !$acc parallel default(present)
      !$acc loop independent
      DO df=loop0_start,loop0_stop
        field1_proxy%data(df) = 0.0_r_def
      END DO
```
Now there is also a '0' and '1' in the copy-in, and while I am not an openacc expert, that just looks wrong :)

title: [LFRic] Incorrect stencil depth list for discontinuous stencil readers followed by discontinuous writers

labels.name: LFRic
labels.description: Issue relates to the LFRic domain

body:
When we have a kernel that has discontinuous stencil readers is followed by a kernel that has discontinuous writers in a single invoke, PSyclone generates incorrect code for stencil depth list string. E.g. as reported from [LFRic/branches/dev/ianboutle/r34895_bl_exp_split@35124](https://code.metoffice.gov.uk/trac/lfric/browser/LFRic/branches/dev/ianboutle/r34895_bl_exp_split?rev=35124) ([LFRic ticket 3205](https://code.metoffice.gov.uk/trac/lfric/ticket/3205)):
```
algorithm/bl_exp_alg_mod_psy.f90(493): error #6642: There are null arguments in an intrinsic function reference.   [MAX]
      IF (u_in_w3_proxy%is_dirty(depth=max(stencil_depth,))) THEN
---------------------------------------^
algorithm/bl_exp_alg_mod_psy.f90(494): error #6642: There are null arguments in an intrinsic function reference.   [MAX]
        CALL u_in_w3_proxy%halo_exchange(depth=max(stencil_depth,))
-----------------------------------------------^
algorithm/bl_exp_alg_mod_psy.f90(497): error #6642: There are null arguments in an intrinsic function reference.   [MAX]
      IF (v_in_w3_proxy%is_dirty(depth=max(stencil_depth,))) THEN
---------------------------------------^
algorithm/bl_exp_alg_mod_psy.f90(498): error #6642: There are null arguments in an intrinsic function reference.   [MAX]
        CALL v_in_w3_proxy%halo_exchange(depth=max(stencil_depth,))
-----------------------------------------------^
algorithm/bl_exp_alg_mod_psy.f90(501): error #6642: There are null arguments in an intrinsic function reference.   [MAX]
      IF (tile_fraction_proxy%is_dirty(depth=max(stencil_depth,))) THEN
---------------------------------------------^
algorithm/bl_exp_alg_mod_psy.f90(502): error #6642: There are null arguments in an intrinsic function reference.   [MAX]
        CALL tile_fraction_proxy%halo_exchange(depth=max(stencil_depth,))
```

Closer inspection into the `dynamo0p3.py` function [`def _compute_halo_depth`](https://github.com/stfc/PSyclone/blob/ffd115beb3990679bff78e390f9909353ba073b0/src/psyclone/dynamo0p3.py#L5950) reveals that the problem lies in this check
```
        if len(depth_info_list) == 1:
            return str(depth_info_list[0])
```
because call to [`_compute_halo_read_depth_info`](https://github.com/stfc/PSyclone/blob/ffd115beb3990679bff78e390f9909353ba073b0/src/psyclone/dynamo0p3.py#L5961) may return an **empty string** which is **still counted as a list element**.

A print-out of `depth_info_list` and `depth_str_list` for a combination of two test-file kernels
```
 call invoke(                                                       &
       testkern_different_any_dscnt_space_stencil_type(f1,          &
                                                       f2, extent,  &
                                                       f4, extent), &
       testkern_w3_type(a, f1, f2, f3, f4)                          &
       )
``` 
returns something like 
```
depth_info_list:  [<psyclone.dynamo0p3.HaloDepth object at 0x7fe4d23fc710>, <psyclone.dynamo0p3.HaloDepth object at 0x7fe4d23fcf60>]
depth_str_list:  ['extent', '1']
depth_info_list:  [<psyclone.dynamo0p3.HaloDepth object at 0x7fe4d2272940>, <psyclone.dynamo0p3.HaloDepth object at 0x7fe4d2272400>]
depth_str_list:  ['extent', '']
```

Interestingly, this problem doesn't appear when
- The kernel with discontinuous stencil access is placed after a kernel with discontinuous writers in a single invoke;
- The kernel with discontinuous stencil access and kernel with discontinuous writers are in different invokes;
-  One or both kernels have continuous stencil access or/and readers.

A simple fix is to first create `depth_str_list` from `depth_info_list`, filter it for empty entries and then check the length of `depth_str_list`.

title: [Frontend] PR #1670 breaks the ability to process NEMO code
body:
Merged PR #1670, which simplifies the symbol tables of the nodes in the PsyIR, breaks the ability to process NEMO code. I suspect (but @sergisiso can probably correct me here) that this is due to existing bugs/inconsistencies that are simply resurfacing rather than the introduction of new bugs.

- [ ] Routines, such as Fortran functions, with symbol `RoutineSymbol<DeferredType>` lose tag `own_routine_symbol`. It appears that these routines initially get the tag associated with symbol `RoutineSymbol<NoType>` but later lose it when this is converted to a specific return type, e.g. `DataSymbol<Scalar<INTEGER, UNDEFINED>, Local>`. NEMO file `domvvl.f90` contains function `dom_vvl_alloc()` which triggers the behaviour when the PSyIR is generated.

- [ ] The letter case of the symbols added to the tables is inconsistent complicating string comparisons. I suggest storing them in their original case for symbols from case-sensitive languages and in lowercase for case-insensitive languages such as Fortran.

- [ ] Fortran USE statements broken into (at least) one continuation line using an ampersand are wrongly parsed/interpreted leading to errors due to unrecognised entities which PSyclone wrongly says are never imported. This happens when processing both `julian.f90` and `obs_conv.f90`. These files/modules can be skipped with no performance penalty since, even before merging PR#1670, no optimisation was being successfully applied.

- [ ] For some reason, when processing `obs_read_surf.f90`, PSyclone tries to swap a symbol in a nonexistent table. This file/module can also be skipped with no performance penalty since it is marked for profiling only.

title: Symbols representing LFRic BuiltIn Functors

labels.name: LFRic
labels.description: Issue relates to the LFRic domain

labels.name: PSyIR
labels.description: Core PSyIR functionality

body:
Currently, creating an LFRicBuiltinFunctor is done like so:

    setval_c = DataTypeSymbol("setval_c", DeferredType())
    LFRicBuiltinFunctor.create(setval_c, [Reference(sym), Literal("1.0", rdef_type)])

However, this has two problems:

  1. It requires that the user create a DataTypeSymbol of the appropriate name first;
  2. That symbol must be removed in any lowering performed by the backend as otherwise it is undefined.
 
Since a BuiltIn is part of the LFRic API, it seems that it perhaps shouldn't have to refer to a symbol at all (or, if it does, then it should be handled by the constructor) and, if we decide it does, then that symbol should definitely be removed by the lowering performed in the backend.

title: [PSyAD] Problem with uninitialised array accessed in loop
body:
The TL hydrostatic kernel in `examples/psyad/eg2` contains a local array that is initialised in a loop:

    do df = 1, ndf_wt
      theta_v_e(df) = ls_theta_v_e(df) * theta( map_wt(df) + k ) /  ls_theta( map_wt(df) + k )  + &
           ls_theta_v_e(df) * moist_dyn_gas( map_wt(df) + k ) / ls_moist_dyn_gas( map_wt(df) + k ) - &
           ls_theta_v_e(df) * moist_dyn_tot( map_wt(df) + k ) / ls_moist_dyn_tot( map_wt(df) + k )
    end do

and then subsequently used:

        do df = 1, ndf_wt
          theta_v_at_quad   = theta_v_at_quad + theta_v_e(df)*wt_basis(1,df,qp1,qp2)
        end do

The corresponding code that we generate in the adjoint is:

          do df = ndf_wt, 1, -1
            theta_v_e(df) = theta_v_e(df) + theta_v_at_quad * wt_basis(1,df,qp1,qp2)
          enddo
    ...
      do df = ndf_wt, 1, -1
        theta(map_wt(df) + k) = theta(map_wt(df) + k) + ls_theta_v_e(df) * theta_v_e(df) / ls_theta(map_wt(df) + k)
        moist_dyn_gas(map_wt(df) + k) = moist_dyn_gas(map_wt(df) + k) + ls_theta_v_e(df) * theta_v_e(df) / ls_moist_dyn_gas(map_wt(df) + k)
        moist_dyn_tot(map_wt(df) + k) = moist_dyn_tot(map_wt(df) + k) - ls_theta_v_e(df) * theta_v_e(df) / ls_moist_dyn_tot(map_wt(df) + k)
        theta_v_e(df) = 0.0
      enddo

The problem here is that we read from `theta_v_e(df)` *before* we have written to it (and in fact, when we do it is only to write zero).

title: [fparser2-FE] Conversion of WHERE to canonical form fails if array notation is missing

labels.name: NEMOVAR
labels.description: Relating to the NEMOVAR code.

body:
Routine bkg_mxl_kara in bkg.F90 in NEMOVAR:

    WHERE( pmsk%tmask(:,:,1) /= 1.0_wp )
       ll_found = .TRUE.
    END WHERE

becomes

     do widx2_1 = 1, SIZE(pmsk%tmask, 2), 1
        do widx1_1 = 1, SIZE(pmsk%tmask, 1), 1
          if (pmsk%tmask(widx1_1,widx2_1,1) /= 1.0_wp) then
             ll_found = .true.
          end if
        enddo

i.e. we fail to spot the missing array notation on the LHS of the assignment and proceed to convert it to canonical form but get it wrong because there are no array ranges to convert.

title: [fparser2-FE] Visibility of symbols imported from other modules is lost

labels.name: NEMOVAR
labels.description: Relating to the NEMOVAR code.

body:
The various type definitions imported via USE statements in the following code:

    MODULE jb_def
     USE bge_ctl_def, ONLY :  fbge_ctl_typ             !: Control parameters for background error covariance
     USE bge_def, ONLY :  fbge_typ                 !: Background error covariance data structure
     USE ens_ctl_def, ONLY : fens_ctl_typ             !: Control parameters for ensemble estimation
     USE ens_typ, ONLY :  fens_typ                 !: Ensemble estimation data structure
     USE eof_ctl_def, ONLY :  feof_ctl_typ             !: Control parameters for EOFs
     USE eof_typ, ONLY :  feof_typ                 !: EOF data structure
     USE bal_ctl_def, ONLY :  fbal_ctl_typ             !: Balance operator control
     USE bal_typ, ONLY :  fbal_typ                 !: Balance operator data structure
     USE control_vectors, ONLY :  ctlvec
     USE variables, ONLY :  fvariables_typ            !: Control vector variables

     IMPLICIT NONE

     !! * Routine accessibility
     PRIVATE

     PUBLIC  fjb_typ                  !: Jb data structure

     PUBLIC  fbge_ctl_typ,  fbge_typ, fens_ctl_typ, fens_typ, fbal_ctl_typ, fbal_typ

     TYPE fjb_typ

        TYPE(fbge_ctl_typ)   ::  fbge_ctl             !: Control parameters for background error covariance
        TYPE(fbge_typ    )   ::  fbge                 !: Background error covariance data structure
        TYPE(fens_ctl_typ)   ::  fens_ctl             !: Control parameters for ensemble estimation
        TYPE(fens_typ    )   ::  fens                 !: Ensemble estimation data structure
        TYPE(feof_ctl_typ)   ::  feof_ctl             !: Control parameters for EOFs
        TYPE(feof_typ    )   ::  feof                 !: EOF data structure
        TYPE(fbal_ctl_typ)   ::  fbal_ctl             !: Balance operator control
        TYPE(fbal_typ)       ::  fbal                 !: Balance operator data structure
        TYPE(fvariables_typ) ::  fbkg_vars
        TYPE(fvariables_typ) :: fbge_vars

        TYPE(ctlvec), POINTER :: x_bkg               !: Background control vector

     END TYPE fjb_typ

    END MODULE jb_def

should be public but when we re-generate the code we lose this information. Possibly this is because there are two `PUBLIC` statements and we only spot the first?

body:
NEMOVAR has the following function:

    ! Return a variable by character key
    FUNCTION get_var( c_key )

      CHARACTER(LEN=jp_var_name_max_len), INTENT(IN) :: c_key
      TYPE(fvar_typ), POINTER :: get_var

      INTEGER :: ilen

      ilen = LEN(c_key)
      CALL gvars_list%get( c_key(1:MIN(ilen, jp_var_name_max_len)), this )
      SELECT TYPE(self => this)
      TYPE IS (fvar_typ)
         get_var => self
      CLASS DEFAULT
         CALL abort
      END SELECT

    END FUNCTION get_var

and we get an index-out-of-range because we expect a TYPE or CLASS declaration to always have an associated `Fortran2003.Type_Name`. We need to fix this at line 1532 of psyir/frontend/fparser2.py.

```
do jj = 1, jpj, 1
  do ji = 1, jpi, 1
    pah1(ji,jj,jk) = pahs1(ji,jj) * (zratio + zc * (1._wp + TANH(- (gdept_0(:, :, jk) - zh) * zw)))

```

```
18 File "/opt/hostedtoolcache/Python/3.8.12/x64/lib/python3.8/site-packages/psyclone/expression.py", line 338, in <module> 
19 OPERATOR = pparse.operatorPrecedence( 
20AttributeError: module 'pyparsing' has no attribute 'operatorPrecedence'

when running the examples. Is this a known issue (it all works for me). Github uses pyparsing 3.0.1, while I still have 2.4.7
```

According to https://pyparsing-docs.readthedocs.io/en/latest/whats_new_in_3_0_0.html#other-discontinued-features `operatorPrecedence `is deprecated, and ` infixNotation` should be used, which indeed fixes the issue.

title: [psyad] use consistent precision within generated test-harness code.
body:
Currently the test harness generated as part of the PSyAD example sometimes reports success and sometimes failure.

There are two reasons for this:

 - [x] The fields are declared as REAL but the inner products are calculated using double precision. (We should use the same precision as the fields.)
 - [x] The mechanism used to compare the results does not allow for machine precision and should be replaced by code based upon that supplied by the Met Office.

title: [lfric] Alter the number of cells passed to 'domain' kernels

labels.name: LFRic
labels.description: Issue relates to the LFRic domain

body: Currently PSyclone generates code that passes the number of cells to `domain` kernels as being the result of `mesh%get_ncells_2d()`. However, this causes the UM Physics code to end up looping into halos and bad things happen. We therefore need to change this to use `mesh%get_last_edge_cell()` instead.

labels.name: NEMOVAR
labels.description: Relating to the NEMOVAR code.

body:
Simon has reported:

"Apparently unbounded loops with a nested inner loop are incorrectly reproduced: the nested loops of

    PROGRAM x
      INTEGER :: y
      DO
        DO y=1,2
        END DO
      END DO
    END PROGRAM x

are currently transformed into two nested loops with identical loop variables and parameters."

I would have expected the unbounded loop to result in a CodeBlock so I'm not sure what's going wrong here.

title: [fparser2 frontend] bug in WHERE handling

labels.name: NEMO
labels.description: Issue relates to the NEMO domain

body:
Simon has reported: apparently some WHERE constructs are incorrectly transformed into an IF block without a loop around it plus a near copy of the original WHERE construct. The small example program

    PROGRAM x
      INTEGER, DIMENSION(2) :: y, z
      z(:) = 0
      WHERE (y > z(1))
        y=0
      END WHERE
    END PROGRAM x

Currently we still rely upon the use of array notation when handling WHERE statements so I think the problem here is that the access to `y` in the mask of the WHERE doesn't use it. We are now in a position to do this 'properly' by looking-up the types of the symbols referenced in the mask expression.

title: [psyir] ScopingNode refinecopy() misses loop variable
body: In #1147 I discovered that the ScopingNode._refinecopy() method fails to correctly copy over the variable associated with a loop. This is a fix for that bug.

title: Crash in lower_to_language when a real constant is used as argument in gocean
body:
The following code crashes when calling lower_to_language:
```
    call invoke (init_field(a_fld, 1.0))
```
It does work when the `1.0` is replaced with `1` (but then the compiler complains about passing an integer where a real is expected).
The reason seems to be:
```
        if six.text_type(self.name).isnumeric():
            return Literal(self.name, INTEGER_TYPE)
```
`isnumeric`  (and the rest of this code ;) ) only accepts integer.

I will likely fix this as part of #1288.

title: (closes #1361) Fix PSyIRGen bug and add unit tests for the class
f2pygen PSyIRGen misses nodes if a PSyIR node maps to more than one fparser node
body:
If the PSyIR node provided to PSyIRGen maps to multiple fparser nodes, only the first one is considered, this happens in the  line:
```
BaseGen.__init__(self, parent, fparser1_parser.block.content[0])
```
We need to check for possible remaining content and add it to the f2pygen tree as siblings.

title: (closes #1359) Fix pytest fixtures tear downs
Parallel pytest often fails with unititialised API constants
body:
There are issues with uninitialised API constants when executing the tests in parallel, but serial unit test (like in the CI) or testing file by file do not produce any error.

I can replicate some error with:
`pytest -n 6 src/psyclone/tests/gocean1p0_test.py src/psyclone/tests/psyir/nodes/acc_directives_test.py`
so I assume the interference is between this 2 files.

title: Declaration ordering error

labels.name: NEMO
labels.description: Issue relates to the NEMO domain

labels.name: PSyIR
labels.description: Core PSyIR functionality

body:
If a new Fortran type is declared and then used to define a variable then the ordering of these declarations is not honoured when translating to PSyIR and then back to Fortran. This means that the resulting code will not compile. For example ...
``` 
        type :: field_type
          real :: data(10)
        end type
        type(field_type) :: a
```
is output as ...
```
        type(field_type) :: a
        type :: field_type
          real :: data(10)
        end type
```
which causes a compile error (at least for gfortran).

title: [psyir] Lower bound in Fortran array declarations is not retained

labels.name: NEMO
labels.description: Issue relates to the NEMO domain

labels.name: PSyIR
labels.description: Core PSyIR functionality

body:
In Fortran an array's bounds can be specified within the declaration:

    integer, dimension(0:12) :: my_array

In raising to PSyIR and then lowering again, this information is lost and the resulting array is declared as:

    integer, dimension(12) :: my_array

title: [psyir] Scoping of symbols in imported containers not preserved

labels.name: NEMO
labels.description: Issue relates to the NEMO domain

labels.name: PSyIR
labels.description: Core PSyIR functionality

body:
NEMO uses the following idiom fairly frequently:

    module my_mod
      use some_other_mod
      private
      integer :: some_internal_flag
      integer, public :: my_useful_flag
    contains
      ..
    end module my_mod

Unfortunately, the code that deals with symbol visibility (which I wrote) thinks it can do away with the `private` statement and just declares the accessibility of each symbol explicitly. This means that we end up generating:

    module my_mod
      use some_other_mod
      integer, private :: some_internal_flag
      integer, public :: my_useful_flag
    contains
      ..
    end module my_mod

This then means that any code that does a wildcard import from `my_mod` will now also import all the public symbols from `some_other_mod`. This is incorrect.

title: [psyir] Loop labels not retained but references to them are

labels.name: NEMO
labels.description: Issue relates to the NEMO domain

labels.name: PSyIR
labels.description: Core PSyIR functionality

body:
In Fortran, a loop may be labelled:

    myloop: do i = 1, 10
                    EXIT myloop
    end do myloop

While the EXIT is converted into a CodeBlock and thus retained, the label on the loop itself is lost so the generated code is not correct. A first solution would be to put any labelled loop into a CodeBlock instead.

title: [psyir] Missing comma separator if argument list to a call contains a CodeBlock

labels.name: NEMO
labels.description: Issue relates to the NEMO domain

labels.name: PSyIR
labels.description: Core PSyIR functionality

body:
If we have some code that results in a CodeBlock in the argument list, e.g.:

    call output("hello "//my_string, unit_num=6)

Then the PSyIR is:

    1: Call[name='output']
        CodeBlock[[<class 'fparser.two.Fortran2003.Level_3_Expr'>, <class 'fparser.two.Fortran2003.Actual_Arg_Spec'>]]

But the generated code is:

    call output("hello " // my_stringunit_num = 6)

i.e. we're missing the comma separator between the two arguments.

title: Comparing Signatures under python 2

labels.name: PSyIR
labels.description: Core PSyIR functionality

body:
In #1253 I've re-written things to use Signatures and it has simplified the code. However, when run under Python 2 I get test failures.
I've discovered that if I add the following test to tests/core/signature_test.py:

    def test_signature_comparison():
        ''' Test that two Signatures can be compared for equality. '''
        assert Signature(("a", "b")) == Signature(("a", "b"))
        assert not Signature(("a", "b")) != Signature(("a", "b"))
        assert Signature(("a", "b")) != Signature(("a", "c"))
        assert not Signature(("a", "b")) == Signature(("a", "c"))

then it passes under Python 3 but not under Python 2 (the comparison always yields True in this case).

The first question is, have I understood correctly and therefore this test should pass?
If I have misunderstood and Signatures aren't supposed to allow this kind of comparison, could we extend them so that they can?

title: PSyIR for ranges in derived-type references is wrong

labels.name: PSyIR
labels.description: Core PSyIR functionality

body:
Attempting to compile the Fortran generated from the PSyIR for NEMO has revealed problems with the PSyIR constructed for derived type references, e.g.:

    vars(1)%region%subgrid(3)%data(:) = 1.0
    vars(:)%region%subgrid(3)%xstop

The `Range` nodes introduced still contain references to the 'fake parent' nodes introduced while building the reference. These should in fact be either `StructureReference` or `ArrayOfStructuresReference` nodes.

While working on this, I've also noticed that the code in the Fortran backend that reduces `my_array(LBOUND(my_array, 1):UBOUND(my_array, 1))` to `my_array(:)` doesn't work when the reference is to a derived type.

title: [LFRic] Put in parentheses around exponents in built-ins that raise field elements to a power

labels.name: LFRic
labels.description: Issue relates to the LFRic domain

body:
As reported in LFRic, the following line:

```
call invoke( inc_X_powreal_a(dtrdz_at_w2, -1.0_r_def) )
```
fails to compile with:
```
 error #8810: Consecutive operators are an extension to the Fortran 2008 standard.
        dtrdz_at_w2_proxy%data(df) = dtrdz_at_w2_proxy%data(df)**- 1.0_r_def
```

This is also reported [e.g. here](https://community.intel.com/t5/Intel-Fortran-Compiler/Operation-ordering-for-negative-exponents/m-p/1156951).

Placing parentheses around the negative exponent removes the error. This is in accordanace with Metcalf & Reid, Fortran 95/2003 pp 35: 
**_We note that the minus sign (-) and the plus sign (+) can be used as unary operators, as in   `-tax`.  Because it is not permitted in ordinary mathematical notation, a unary minus or plus must not follow immediately after another operator. When this is needed, as for `x**-y`, parentheses must be placed around the operator and its operand: `x**(-y)`._**

Therefore, it would make sense for PSyclone were to always put in the parentheses around the power except if they are already there (that can be easily checked).

body:
If a GOStencil is set as ``go_pointwise``, you can still query its depth, but you will get ``[000,00,000]``. Either getting the depth of a stencil with ``go_pointwise`` should raise an exception, or (my preferred solution) this should return ``[000,010,000]``. The latter would  imho express the meaning of ``go_pointwise`` adequately (and remove if-tests for some of my dependency code). 

Am happy to fix this as part of #1130, but in case that we don't agree on the best way we have this ticket to discuss this independently. @rupertford , @arporter, @sergisiso

title: RTD builds failing for user and dev guides
body:
After updating to the latest Sphinx (3.5.0) the documentation fails to build with:

    AttributeError: 'str' object has no attribute 'priority'

this is discussed here: https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/issues/8885

It seems we just need to update `html_context` in `conf.py` to use `html_css_files` instead.

I think we simply need to add `bibtex_bibfiles = ['../bibliography/references.bib']` to the relevant `conf.py` (assuming that the relative path is OK).

title: Correct intent for "GH_WRITE" to "inout" in kernels (for #1003)

labels.name: LFRic
labels.description: Issue relates to the LFRic domain

body:
According to Fortran rules the field and operator data arguments in kernels should have `intent(inout)` as they are always defined outside of kernels. However, we currently generate `intent(out)` in LFRic kernels for arguments that have `GH_WRITE` access. This PR corrects the generation and access rules for `GH_WRITE` access to `intent(inout)`. 

P.S. I checked the coverage following the link ["Continue to review full report at Codecov"](https://codecov.io/gh/stfc/PSyclone/pull/1117?src=pr&el=continue) from below and everything there seems accounted for.

title: Bug fix for auto-invoke profiling and return statements (closes #1091)

labels.name: PSyIR
labels.description: Core PSyIR functionality

title: Auto-invoke profiling includes Return nodes.
body:
While testing PSyclone master with NEMO I've discovered that the auto-profiling code does not check for Return nodes in the region to be enclosed. Since the profiling transformation itself *does* check this causes failures. I have a simple fix that does two things:
 1. For the common case where a routine finishes (with a superfluous) 'return', this is removed from the list of nodes passed to the profiling transformation;
 2. For anything more complicated (more than one 'return' or 'return' not the last statement) the code quietly skips adding profiling.

Having written that, I can see we need to log situation 2.

title: [LFRic] adjacent_face array is not aware of colouring with OpenMP

labels.name: LFRic
labels.description: Issue relates to the LFRic domain

body:
This bug was noticed in the [LFRic ticket 2415](https://code.metoffice.gov.uk/trac/lfric/ticket/2415) when running with LFRic with OpenMO and more than one thread.

Currently PSyclone generates
```
      DO colour=1,ncolour
        !$omp parallel default(shared), private(cell)
        !$omp do schedule(static)
        DO cell=1,mesh%get_last_halo_cell_per_colour(colour,1)
          call subroutine(…, adjacent_face(:,cell), …)
          …
```
whereas the correct code should be

```
      DO colour=1,ncolour
        !$omp parallel default(shared), private(cell)
        !$omp do schedule(static)
        DO cell=1,mesh%get_last_halo_cell_per_colour(colour,1)
          call subroutine(…, adjacent_face(:,cmap(colour,cell)), …)
          …
```
For now it is agreed that a small number of LFRic kernels that are implementing this feature will need to be called through PSyKAl-lite until the fix is available through a new PSyclone release.

This also raises the need for more thorough testing on LFRic side (particularly having more multi-threaded jobs in the test suite).

title: The generated OpenCL for GOcean sometimes accesses invalid memory

labels.name: GOcean
labels.description: Issue relates to the GOcean domain

body:
When providing workgroup sizes to the OpenCL back-end (necessary for good performance) the generated code sometimes segfauls due to accessing invalid memory addresses. This is because the original data not always is divisible by the workgroup size.

Additionally the GOcean API has its own padding environment variable that changes the width of the 2D arrays. The kernels should be consistent with this padding.

A possible solution to this issue is to provide the contiguous dimension upper bound as a parameter to the OpenCL kernel. Then simply add the condition `if (ji> upper_bound) return;` at the begging of the kernel.

            a_var = 1.0

          end subroutine test_sub2

title: Bug in Dynamo0p3RedundantComputationTrans (field.call in dynamo0p3.halo_check_arg returns DynHaloExchange)

labels.name: LFRic
labels.description: Issue relates to the LFRic domain

body:
When trying to group built-in and kernel calls in a single invoke in a newly added LFRic algorithm ([LFRic ticket #2185](https://code.metoffice.gov.uk/trac/lfric/ticket/2185#comment:47))
```
 call invoke( name = "initialise vertical_departures", &
    setval_c(dep_pts_z, 0.0_r_def), &
    setval_c(dep_wind_n, 0.0_r_def), &
    setval_c(dep_wind_np1, 0.0_r_def), &
    calc_departure_wind_kernel_type(dep_wind_n, wind, chi), &
    setval_X(dep_wind_np1, dep_wind_n), &
    vertical_trapezoidal_kernel_type(dep_pts_z, dep_wind_n, dep_wind_np1))
```
the `Dynamo0p3RedundantComputationTrans` in the LFRic optimisation script [global.py](https://code.metoffice.gov.uk/trac/lfric/browser/LFRic/trunk/gungho/optimisation/meto-spice/global.py) returns the following error:
```
Generation Error: Generator: script file '/data/users/ikavcic/r24358_split_scheme/gungho/optimisation/meto-spice/global.py'
raised the following exception during execution ...
{
      File "/data/users/ikavcic/r24358_split_scheme/gungho/optimisation/meto-spice/global.py", line 67, in trans
    schedule, _ = rtrans.apply(loop, options={"depth": 1})
      File "/data/users/lfric/modules/packages.rhel7/psyclone/1.9.0/lib/python3.6/site-packages/psyclone/transformations.py", line 2406, in apply
    loop.update_halo_exchanges()
      File "/data/users/lfric/modules/packages.rhel7/psyclone/1.9.0/lib/python3.6/site-packages/psyclone/dynamo0p3.py", line 7160, in update_halo_exchanges
    self.create_halo_exchanges()
      File "/data/users/lfric/modules/packages.rhel7/psyclone/1.9.0/lib/python3.6/site-packages/psyclone/dynamo0p3.py", line 7198, in create_halo_exchanges
    self._add_halo_exchange(halo_field)
      File "/data/users/lfric/modules/packages.rhel7/psyclone/1.9.0/lib/python3.6/site-packages/psyclone/dynamo0p3.py", line 7151, in _add_halo_exchange
    self._add_halo_exchange_code(halo_field)
      File "/data/users/lfric/modules/packages.rhel7/psyclone/1.9.0/lib/python3.6/site-packages/psyclone/dynamo0p3.py", line 7130, in _add_halo_exchange_code
    required, _ = exchange.required()
      File "/data/users/lfric/modules/packages.rhel7/psyclone/1.9.0/lib/python3.6/site-packages/psyclone/dynamo0p3.py", line 5921, in required
    required_clean_info = self._compute_halo_read_depth_info()
      File "/data/users/lfric/modules/packages.rhel7/psyclone/1.9.0/lib/python3.6/site-packages/psyclone/dynamo0p3.py", line 5839, in _compute_halo_read_depth_info
    halo_info_list = self._compute_halo_read_info()
      File "/data/users/lfric/modules/packages.rhel7/psyclone/1.9.0/lib/python3.6/site-packages/psyclone/dynamo0p3.py", line 5859, in _compute_halo_read_info
    in read_dependencies]
      File "/data/users/lfric/modules/packages.rhel7/psyclone/1.9.0/lib/python3.6/site-packages/psyclone/dynamo0p3.py", line 5858, in <listcomp>
    return [HaloReadAccess(read_dependency) for read_dependency
      File "/data/users/lfric/modules/packages.rhel7/psyclone/1.9.0/lib/python3.6/site-packages/psyclone/dynamo0p3.py", line 6543, in __init__
    self._compute_from_field(field)
      File "/data/users/lfric/modules/packages.rhel7/psyclone/1.9.0/lib/python3.6/site-packages/psyclone/dynamo0p3.py", line 6588, in _compute_from_field
    call = halo_check_arg(field, AccessType.all_read_accesses())
      File "/data/users/lfric/modules/packages.rhel7/psyclone/1.9.0/lib/python3.6/site-packages/psyclone/dynamo0p3.py", line 6445, in halo_check_arg
    "found {1}".format(field.name, type(call)))
    psyclone.errors.GenerationError: Generation Error: In HaloInfo class, field 'dep_wind_n' should be from a call but found <class 'psyclone.dynamo0p3.DynHaloExchange'>
```

The problematic combination of calls can be narrowed down to two last calls
```
 call invoke( name = "initialise vertical_departures", &
    setval_X(dep_wind_np1, dep_wind_n), &
    vertical_trapezoidal_kernel_type(dep_pts_z, dep_wind_n, dep_wind_np1))
```

The  `Dynamo0p3RedundantComputationTrans` is applied to `setval_c` and `setval_X` built-in calls to the depth of 1, as can be seen from the optimisation script code:
```
        for loop in schedule.loops():
            if loop.iteration_space == "dofs":
                if len(loop.kernels()) != 1:
                    raise Exception(
                        "Expecting loop to contain 1 call but found '{0}'".
                        format(len(loop.kernels())))
                if loop.kernels()[0].name in ["setval_c", "setval_x"]:
                    setval_count += 1
                    schedule, _ = rtrans.apply(loop, options={"depth": 1})
``` 

Printing the type of `loop.kernels()[0]`, its arguments and the calls of these arguments in the `global.py` optimisation script returns `<class 'psyclone.dynamo0p3_builtins.DynSetvalXKern'>`, `dep_wind_np1`, `dep_wind_n`  and `<class 'psyclone.dynamo0p3_builtins.DynSetvalXKern'>`. Therefore, it is not quite clear how `field.call` manages to become `<class 'psyclone.dynamo0p3.DynHaloExchange'>` by the time the argument call is checked in `dynamo0p3.halo_check_arg` support function.

Interestingly enough, this failure does not happen when the `setval_X` built-in call is placed **after** the `vertical_trapezoidal_kernel_type` call in the invoke (including the previous `setval_c` and `calc_departure_wind_kernel_type` calls not shown below)
```
 call invoke( name = "initialise vertical_departures", &
    vertical_trapezoidal_kernel_type(dep_pts_z, dep_wind_n, dep_wind_np1), &
    setval_X(dep_wind_np1, dep_wind_n) )
```
Also, when the last call to `vertical_trapezoidal_kernel_type` is in a separate invoke
```
 call invoke( name = "initialise vertical_departures", &
    setval_c(dep_pts_z, 0.0_r_def), &
    setval_c(dep_wind_n, 0.0_r_def), &
    setval_c(dep_wind_np1, 0.0_r_def), &
    calc_departure_wind_kernel_type(dep_wind_n, wind, chi), &
    setval_X(dep_wind_np1, dep_wind_n) )
 call invoke( vertical_trapezoidal_kernel_type(dep_pts_z, dep_wind_n, dep_wind_np1) )
```
everything works normally.

The algorithm and kernel files can be found at these links (algorithm is new in the branch from the ticket, kernels already exist in LFRic trunk):
- [calc_vertical_departure_alg_mod.x90](https://code.metoffice.gov.uk/trac/lfric/browser/LFRic/branches/dev/mohamedzerroukat/r24358_split_scheme/gungho/source/algorithm/calc_vertical_departure_alg_mod.x90?rev=24583)
- [calc_departure_wind_kernel_mod.F90](https://code.metoffice.gov.uk/trac/lfric/browser/LFRic/branches/dev/mohamedzerroukat/r24358_split_scheme/gungho/source/kernel/calc_departure_wind_kernel_mod.F90?rev=24518)
- [vertical_trapezoidal_kernel_mod.F90](https://code.metoffice.gov.uk/trac/lfric/browser/LFRic/branches/dev/mohamedzerroukat/r24358_split_scheme/gungho/source/kernel/vertical_trapezoidal_kernel_mod.F90?rev=24518)

    CALL profile_psy_data0 % PreStart('sw_ptmp', 'r0', 0, 0)

    del_th = del_P * sw_adtg(S, T, P)

    RETURN
    CALL profile_psy_data0 % PostEnd

title: [NEMO] Dimensioning variable with DeferredType causes crash
body:
The following code:

    subroutine mysub()
        use some_mod, only: jpi, jpj
        integer, dimension(jpi, jpj) :: some_array
    end subroutine

causes a crash in in `_parse_dimensions()` in the fparser2 frontend. This is because `jpi`/`jpj` have been found in the `use` statement and added to the symbol table with `DeferredType`. This then does not have an `intrinsic_type` which the code in `_parse_dimensions` expects:

                        sym = symbol_table.lookup(dim_name)
                        if (sym.datatype.intrinsic !=
                                ScalarType.Intrinsic.INTEGER or
                                isinstance(sym.datatype, ArrayType)):
                            _unsupported_type_error(dimensions)

title: Duplicate orientation declarations for operators in PSy layer

labels.name: LFRic
labels.description: Issue relates to the LFRic domain

body:
Whilst adding compilation testing for modified test kerenels and examples in #764 I noticed that test example `4.3_multikernel_invokes.f90` (`test_multikern_invoke_orient` in `dynamo0p3_test.py`) fails to compile as it generates two identical declarations of for orientation in PSy layer when calling the same kernel twice:

'''
INTEGER(KIND=i_def), pointer :: orientation_w2(:) => null(), orientation_w2(:) => null()
'''

This happens because `_invoke_declarations` function in `class DynOrientations(DynCollection)` does not check for duplicates in the declaration list.

title: PSyclone fails to understand literal precision in parameter initialization expressions
body:
I tried to psyclone-generate the OpenCL version of NemoLite2D with PSyclone master and I got the following error:
```psyclone.errors.InternalError: PSyclone internal error: Failed to find a symbol table to which to add the kind symbol 'go_wp'.```

This occurs while importing external global variables declarations from a module, specifically in the expression:
```REAL(go_wp), PARAMETER :: pi    = 3.1415926535897932_go_wp```
if I remove the "_go_wp" it fails in the following line:
```REAL(go_wp), PARAMETER :: d2r   = pi / 180```
with the error:
```psyclone.psyir.symbols.symbol.SymbolError: PSyclone SymbolTable error: No Symbol found for name 'pi'.```

If I replace `pi` with its value then it works fine again.

I think the problem is that `literal_precision` tries to find the symbol_table of its parent, but parameters use a dummy node to evaluate the initialisation expression.

title: Fix PSyIR Fortran backend precedence bug (issue #766)

labels.name: PSyIR
labels.description: Core PSyIR functionality

body:
The PSyIR Fortran backend will currently output
`a=b*(c+d)` as `a=b*c+d`.
This PR fixes this bug.

title: Operator ordering broken in PSyiR Fortran back-end

labels.name: PSyIR
labels.description: Core PSyIR functionality

body: The Fortran back-end will write out `a*(b+c)` as a*b+c. As suggested by @sergisiso, the simplest solution would be to add brackets around all unary, binary and nary operators. This is what he already does in the C backend.

title: Make Wchi function space read-only

labels.name: LFRic
labels.description: Issue relates to the LFRic domain

body:
PR #734 adds support for `Wchi` function space that holds coordinate fields in LFRic. The peculiarity of this function space is that the fields on it are read-only when it comes to PSy layer. Coordinate fields are created during the LFRic model setup and not updated afterwards. Consequently, LFRic does not perform halo exchanges on them.
This issue builds on #734 by introducing checks on `Wchi` access metadata (only allowing `GH_READ`) and making sure there is no generated code for halo exchanges on `Wchi` space.
The LFRic ticket [2176](https://code.metoffice.gov.uk/trac/lfric/ticket/2176) will explicitly make these fields read-only in LFRic.

title: Shorten use of ANY_DISCONTINUOUS_SPACE and ANY_SPACE in PSy layer and kernel stub generator

labels.name: LFRic
labels.description: Issue relates to the LFRic domain

body:
Dynamo0.3 API uses full function-space metadata names to create unique variable names in PSy layer and kernel-stub generator. This may lead to problems and too long variable names. A specific example from the generated code that creates compilation error with both Gnu and Intel compilers is
```
algorithm/runtime_constants_mod_psy.f90(2537): error #6439: This symbol has too many characters.   [BASIS_ANY_SPACE_9_CHI_XYZ_ON_ANY_DISCONTINU]
      REAL(KIND=r_def), allocatable :: basis_any_space_9_chi_xyz_on_any_discontinuous_space_1_latitude_w3(:,:,:)
```
Ben Shipway believes that the maximum variable name in Fortran is 63 characters. However, the truncation above indicates 43. This needs to be checked.

To overcome this issue it was suggested to leave the function space metadata as they are but use short version of their names in PSy layer and kernel-stub generator. Current suggestion for use of `ANY_DISCONTINUOUS_SPACE` metadata in code generation is `any_d_space`, but better ideas are welcome. There will be a separate issue for a short name for `ANY_SPACE` metadata when generating code.

This should be done together with #415 (so we have only one change to the PsyData API)

title: [PSyIR frontend] Parsing of allocatable array declaration fails.
body:
When given the following code (taken from the tra_adv.f90 example):

    PROGRAM tra_adv
       INTEGER, PARAMETER :: wp = 8
       REAL(wp), ALLOCATABLE, SAVE, DIMENSION(:,:,:,:) :: t3sn, t3ns, t3ew, t3we

the fparser2 frontend raises an InternalError saying that it has found an allocatable array with defined extent. This is because it (src/psyclone/psyir/frontend/fparser2.py, 741) checks whether `extent` is `None` when in fact it is `DataSymbol.Extent.xxx`.

title: KernelGlobalsToArguments does not set kernel.modified=True
body: The `apply` method needs to set the `modified` property of the transformed kernel to True. This then facilitates validation checks in other transformations and also ensures that a re-named version of the kernel is written to file. Currently the transformed kernel is not re-named.

title: [LFRic] Support for Wchi function space

labels.name: LFRic
labels.description: Issue relates to the LFRic domain

body:
Whilst reviewing PR #532, @rupertford asked a very good question - why are we not supporting `Wchi` space? 
After some exploration of the LFRic trunk, it seems that `Wchi` is not actually used. The coordinate fields (`chi`) metadata are defined as `ANY_SPACE_9` in the kernels. `chi_space` is set  to `W0` in `runtime_constant_alg_mod.x90` if  `coordinate_order == 0` and to `Wchi` otherwise and we are running with order 0 on trunk.

So, my questions to @thomasmelvin are:
- Are we planning to use `Wchi` at some point?
- If we use `Wchi`, should metadata for `chi` fields in kernels then be `Wchi` and not `ANY_SPACE_9`?

title: Update built-ins accesses in LFRic

labels.name: LFRic
labels.description: Issue relates to the LFRic domain

body:
There are quite a few "user-like" kernels in PSyclone with `GH_WRITE` access for continuous fields (#138). The built-ins are defined over `ANY_SPACE` and by the check in #138 it would not be allowed to have `GH_WRITE` access for them. However, this restriction for function space continuity is not valid for built-ins as they loop over DoFs.

@rupertford suggested that we would actually need to use `GH_WRITE` for built-ins that only write to a field (e.g. `setval_c`) and `GH_READWRITE` instead of `GH_INC` for built-ins that update a field (e.g. `inc_X_plus_Y`).

`GH_WRITE` will still be forbidden for the user-supplied kernels that iterate over `cells` on `ANY_SPACE` as it is treated as continuous and requires colouring.

This ticket will explore this approach by
1) Modifiying the current, quite inconsistent, accesses in `dynamo0p3_builtins_mod.F90`
2) Making sure that  access and transformation logic for looping over DoFs are correct.

title: Handling of scalar grid properties in OpenCL
body: If a scalar grid property (say `go_grid_dx_const`) is used in opencl, the created code can not be compiled since it will contain a reference to `dx_device`.

title: Loop boundaries are not defined when transformations are applied
body:
At least in gocean1.0 the loop boundaries and step size are only defined when gen_code() is being called:
```
def gen_code(self, parent):
 [...]
       self._start = self._lower_bound()
       self._stop = self._upper_bound()
       Loop.gen_code(self, parent)
```
And self._step does not even appear to be set (though it will default to '1' in this case).

This means that transformation can not access loop boundaries, and dependency analysis will be missing accesses. This might be somewhat related to #385 (to convert loop boundaries from strings to PSyIR nodes).

title: Variable Access API
body:
This pull requests add functionality to determine variable accesses in the PSyIR. As discussed the access data stored now includes a pointer to the original node.

The API is used to properly determine thread-private variables in omp transforms.

title: Non-ASCII char in PSy code causes write() to fail
body:
NEMO has some non-standard characters inside character strings (primarily the degree symbol). Although this is not valid Fortran, obviously most compilers cope with it and therefore so should PSyclone. So far this has only tripped me up on Isambard with Python 3.5.1. It isn't a problem on Glados (2.7.15). It is the following in generator.py that falls over:

    elif args.opsy is not None:
        my_file = open(args.opsy, "w")
        my_file.write(psy_str)
        my_file.close()

title: isinstance issues when using a script in PSyclone
body:
I am using a PSyclone script (i.e. used with -s), which contains the following code:
```
from psyclone.PsyGen import Assignment, CodeBlock, IfBlock, TransInfo
 ...
    print(type(mynode))
    print(Assignment)
    if isinstance(mynode, Assignment):
        return True
```
Output:
```
<class 'psyclone.psyGen.Assignment'>
<class 'psyclone.PsyGen.Assignment'>
```
So even though according to the print statement mynode is an Assignment, the if statement is NOT triggered. But if I add:
```
from psyclone import psyGen
...
    if isinstance(mynode, psyGen.Assignment):
        return True
```
then the condition is triggered. Same happens with psyGen.CodeBlock, but NemoLoop is fine, it works without nemo.NemoLoop.

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/38514730/isinstance-returns-false-when-the-fully-qualified-object-class-differs-from-th?rq=1 might explain what the issue is, that Assignment is accessed via two different ways somehow??? sys.path is indeed modified when using a script as far as I know, but in my case the script is outside of the PSyclone tree. 

Low priority for me, using psyGen.<class> works for me


x-failing test is added in my branch nemo_two_loops_in_if.
I have started to debug this, something goes wrong in the line 2734 of psyGen.py:
```
        parent = self._parent.ast
        while parent:
            if hasattr(parent, "content") and \
               parent is not self.children[0].ast:
                break
            parent = parent._parent
```
For the first loop, the while loop is executed twice, while for the second omp-directive the loop is only executed once (which then means it can't find a start index). I am not yet sure what goes wrong - if the first omp+loop subtree creates an incorrect tree, ... 


I am happy to debug this, but if anyone has an idea or suggestion (or even better ... a fix), feel free to take this ticket :)

title: Fix graphviz detection
body: Fixes #392 (test if graphviz is available).

title: Availability of graphviz is tested incorrectly
body:
ATm conftest.py uses the following code to test if graphviz is available:
```
import sys
return "graphviz" in sys.modules
```
This only works if graphviz has been imported. If only a subset of the tests is run, this might not be the case. I think the correct solution is to try-import here.

title: Wrong working directory ... or: PSyclone install does not install psyclone.cfg in a local install
body:
When I do a ``pip install --user -e .``, it appears that no psyclone.cfg is installed in a local directory, while a system-wide install will copy this file to /usr/share/psyclone.

So far this worked for me because I have a custom config file in psyclone/tests/.psyclone, which is used in most tests. But I just stumbled across some tests do a chdir to a temporary directory, and then NOT a chdir back to the original directory. Which means that the next test that is run will have the previous test's temporary directory as working directory. If additionally the latter test reloads the config file (since that is what it is supposed to test), now psyclone cannot find my .../psyclone/tests/,psyclone config file anymore (since it only tests .psyclone/psyclone.cfg), so the tests fail with config file not found. Doing a system-wide install fixes the problem (since psyclone always checks /usr/share/psyclone).

As a first solution I have fixed up the tests in my current branch to do a chdir back to the original directory, but that only solves the problem partially: if a test in a temporary directory should fail an assert, the chdir back is not executed, and the next test may fail because it has an unexpected working directory again :(

Two solutions that I can see:
1) we fix the install process in case of a local installation so that the psyclone.cfg file is copied to $HOME/.local/share/psyclone. --> All tests would find this config file since it is always tested for in config find_file().
2) We add a fixture in conftest that is executed for ALL tests (or at least the ones that chdir to a directory) that will make sure the chdir back to the original directory at the end (or at the beginning of each test).

The first one seems to be the easier solution, but I don't understand why it is not installed in the first place :)

title: Make kernel parse-tree search case insensitive
body: Closes #345

title: Incorrect stencil access for field vectors
body:
When trying to access a stencil (cross) from a `chi(3)` field, PSyclone is generating the following: 
```
chi_stencil_map => chi_proxy%vspace%get_stencil_dofmap(STENCIL_CROSS,1)
 ```
when it should actually be
```
chi_stencil_map => chi_proxy(1)%vspace%get_stencil_dofmap(STENCIL_CROSS,1)
```
For info, the `chi` field is on `ANY_SPACE_2`  in the below metadata:
```
type, public, extends(kernel_type) :: one2one_w2_filter_stencil_kernel_type
    private
    type(arg_type) :: meta_args(4) = (/                       &
        arg_type(GH_FIELD,   GH_WRITE, W3),                   & 
        arg_type(GH_FIELD,   GH_READ,  W3, STENCIL(CROSS)),   & 
        arg_type(GH_FIELD,   GH_READ,  ANY_SPACE_1, STENCIL(CROSS)),    &
        arg_type(GH_FIELD*3, GH_READ,  ANY_SPACE_2, STENCIL(CROSS))    &
        /)
    type(func_type) :: meta_funcs(1) = (/     &
        func_type(ANY_SPACE_2, GH_DIFF_BASIS) &
        /)
    integer :: iterates_over = CELLS
    integer :: gh_shape = GH_EVALUATOR
  contains
    procedure, nopass :: one2one_w2_filter_stencil_code
  end type
```

title: Fix handling of unicode characters in source (py36 and below).
body:
This PR fixes a bug seen with PSyclone and Python 3.6 and below relating to unicode characters in Fortran comments. The file I saw this in was in the LFRic ``algorithm/iterative_solvers/diagonal_preconditioner_mod.x90`` file. The [line in question](https://code.metoffice.gov.uk/trac/lfric/browser/LFRic/trunk/gungho/source/kernel/held_suarez_fv_kernel_mod.F90?rev=14423#L14) has a unicode dash:

```
!> non-hydrostatic models. Q.J.R. Meteorol. Soc., 135: 469–484.
```

Traceback along the lines of:

```
Full psyclone working/unit-tests/algorithm/slow_physics_alg_mod.x90
Error, unexpected exception, please report to the authors:
Description ...
'ascii' codec can't decode byte 0xe2 in position 783: ordinal not in range(128)
Type ...
<class 'UnicodeDecodeError'>
Stacktrace ...
  File "/data/users/itpe/modules/packages/production-os42-1/psyclone/master/psyclone/generator.py", line 396, in main
    kern_naming=args.kernel_renaming)
  File "/data/users/itpe/modules/packages/production-os42-1/psyclone/master/psyclone/generator.py", line 222, in generate
    line_length=line_length)
  File "/data/users/itpe/modules/packages/production-os42-1/psyclone/master/psyclone/parse/algorithm.py", line 102, in parse
    return my_parser.parse(alg_filename)
  File "/data/users/itpe/modules/packages/production-os42-1/psyclone/master/psyclone/parse/algorithm.py", line 220, in parse
    invoke_call = self.create_invoke_call(statement)
  File "/data/users/itpe/modules/packages/production-os42-1/psyclone/master/psyclone/parse/algorithm.py", line 268, in create_invoke_call
    kernel_call = self.create_kernel_call(argument)
  File "/data/users/itpe/modules/packages/production-os42-1/psyclone/master/psyclone/parse/algorithm.py", line 305, in create_kernel_call
    kernel_name, args)
  File "/data/users/itpe/modules/packages/production-os42-1/psyclone/master/psyclone/parse/algorithm.py", line 374, in create_coded_kernel_call
    self._kernel_path, self._line_length)
  File "/data/users/itpe/modules/packages/production-os42-1/psyclone/master/psyclone/parse/kernel.py", line 195, in get_kernel_ast
    check_line_length(filepath)
  File "/data/users/itpe/modules/packages/production-os42-1/psyclone/master/psyclone/parse/utils.py", line 100, in check_line_length
    code_str = myfile.read()
  File "/opt/scitools/environments/production/2019_01_08/lib/python3.6/encodings/ascii.py", line 26, in decode
```

I suspect we will see similar issues on fparser, but haven't yet started looking into that.

title: Global Variables in psyGen causes test failures
body:
While working on #257, I have discovered the magic of psyGen.MAPPINGS_ACCESSES, which is used to map from the internal access mode like 'read' to the API-specific access string 'gh_read'. There is some really sophisticated coding involved in managing this global variable, and while I managed to get it to work with gocean, this then broke some psyGen tests. Basically what happens is that when importing dynamo0p3 it modifies psyGen's variable. Which means that depending on the order of imports psyGen.MAPPINGS_ACCESS is either defined for dynamo, or gocean, and in at least one test case it happens to be the wrong one.

I'd suggest to avoid overwriting (or more precisely even using) this global variable, by moving this functionality into the api-specific config section. For example:
```
[dynamo0.3]
  access_mapping = read:gh_read, write=gh_write, ...
[gocean0.1]
  access_mapping = read:go_read, write=go_write, ...
```
Then we would also have to define a 'current' API in the config class, so psyGen can do:
```
Config.get().getCurrentAPI().getMappingAccesses() 
```
(or maybe even short: ``Config.get().getMappingAccess()``)

In case of typical PSyclone usage, the 'currentAPI' would be defined by the --api command line option. In case of tests each test would have to define the API (which could mostly done once-per-test-file using a fixture), and if there is a mixture of APIs used in one file, this might to have to be done from test to test. 

Besides fixing failed tests because of the import order, it would actually move some infrastructure specific strings into the config file. Imho PSyclone should try not to use any infrastructure specific strings (this would make it easier to add different infrastructure libraries without modifying PSyclone), and this would be a nice start for that.

Feedback welcome :)

title: xpassing test on master
body:
Master has an xpassing test. I think this is down to a merge for one of @hiker s PRs and am therefore assigning it to him in the first instance to check.

```
> pytest tests/gocean1p0_transformations_test.py::test_module_inline_and_compile
```

title: Validate method of kernel-inline transformation does not check for module variables
body: If a kernel is inlined that has a use statement, the resulting code can not be compiled. While this is a documented issue (see class KernelModuleInlineTrans), the inline transform should raise a proper error in this case. Note that this also effects some test cases, which can not be compiled during testing because of this restriction.

title: Compilation test in utilities_test.py not working
body:
It seems to happen only on some installations (guess might depend on hardware, or python version??), but the test_compiler_works() function does not always work as expected. I verified this by modifying the sample Fortran code to be invalid - the test on one of my systems still succeeded (though not on all).

Reason is that (under unknown circumstances) at the time the compiler is called, the file was not flushed (because it was not closed):
```
    try:
        with open("hello_world.f90", "w") as ffile:
            ffile.write(HELLO_CODE)
            success = _compile.compile_file("hello_world.f90", link=True)
```
While the fix (moving the compile_file called back one level, out of the with statement) is trivial, I propose to do a better test by actually trying to link the file (which fails since the compiler compiles an empty file, so it has no main, so linking fails). I'm fixing this as part of my compilation tests for gocean.

title: halo exchange removal for vectors is broken
body: When redundant computation is applied to a loop it can result in halo exchanges no longer being required.  To support this, halo exchanges implement their own `required` method which checks if they are needed or not. However, when redundant computation results in a set of halo exchanges associated with a vector field then only the first of these is removed. A similar issue occurs wih asynchronous halo exchanges. See tests `test_vector_halo_exchange_remove()` and `test_vector_async_halo_exchange()` in `dynamo0p3_transformations_test.py`, currently on the branch associated with issue #214.

A x-failing test case is in:

https://github.com/hiker/PSyclone/blob/openmp-test/src/psyclone/tests/gocean1p0_transformations_test.py
(test_omp_region_with_slice_change_order, lines 290)

Note that my monitoring hooks have a fixed that should solve those issues, and I am happy once the monitoring hooks are merged to master to fix this issue properly.

title: Possible bug: `Call._name_space_manager` is not initialised in class constructor
body:
Instead, it is initialised in `Call.reduction_sum_loop()`. Its value is used in various places within this class without any other attempts to initialise it. This looks highly suspect (unless I've missed something).

I propose that `_name_space_manager` be added to the `Node` base class and initialised in that class' constructor.

title: DAG creation fails for GOcean 1.0 API
body:
In some circumstances, calling the `dag()` method on a GOcean Schedule results in the error:

    AttributeError: 'GOKernelGridArgument' object has no attribute 'forward_dependence'

We will fix this problem in this issue.

title: Disallow GH_WRITE access for continuous fields

labels.name: LFRic
labels.description: Issue relates to the LFRic domain

body:
Although `GH_WRITE` access is officially not allowed for continuous fields in the Dynamo0.3 API there is no explicit restriction and test to reject this combination in PSyclone.
This issue will add the restriction, similar to how it is being done in #25 for `GH_READWRITE` access for continuous fields (`class DynArgDescriptor03(Descriptor):` in `dynamo0p3.py` and related tests in `dynamo0p3_test.py`).

The instances of continuous `GH_WRITE` access in PSyclone code and LFRic kernels will have to be replaced with `GH_INC`. To test for any undesirable side effects in LFRic I replaced `GH_WRITE` continuous instances (only `W0` and `W2` were found) with `GH_INC` in a working copy of the trunk. The good news is that all tests successfully complete (compilation, runs and KGOs checks). It would perhaps be good to warn LFRic developers not to add any more continuous `GH_WRITE` until the PSyclone restriction is in place - more work to remove them later :)

**Update**
It was agreed that this approach will be adopted for the user-supplied kernels that operate over `cells`. Built-ins can use `GH_WRITE` and `GH_READWRITE` on `ANY_SPACE` as they loop over DoFs (see #471).

title: algen tests contains xfailing tests that should now pass
body: While reviewing another issue I noticed that there are a couple of tests in `alggen_test.py` that are marked as xfail because they require multiple quadrature objects to be passed in to a single invoke. However, PSyclone does now support that (since #76 I think) and so these tests should be passing.

title: Bug when using a constant for a scalar kernel parameter
body:
When a kernel is invoked as:
```
  call invoke( bc_ssh(0, p_fld) )
```
with a constant value as the scalar parameter  (bc_ssh is unchanged from the test files):
```
  type, extends(kernel_type) :: bc_ssh
     type(arg), dimension(3) :: meta_args =        &
          (/ arg(READ,      R_SCALAR, POINTWISE),  &
             arg(READWRITE, CT,       POINTWISE),  &
             arg(READ,      GRID_MASK_T)           &
           /)
```
the code created includes:
```
REAL(KIND=wp), intent(inout) :: 0
```
In https://github.com/hiker/PSyclone/tree/constant-parameter I've created an x-failing test to show this, not sure if you want a pull request for the test itself. Easy work around of course: declare a variable zero=0.

title: Remove halo exchange when read to annexed dofs precedes write to halo l1
body: At the moment a halo exchange is added when a fields annexed dofs are read after a field has its l1 halo written and this is not required. The dynamo/eg8 test on master assumes such a halo exchange is not produced and therefore currently does not work.

title: valid fortran names should be created from named invoke labels
body:
Fortran call and subroutine names must obey certain rules. For example, they must start with a character and should not contain unsupported characters. At the moment we do not check for this so invalid names can be specified. For example ...
```
name="_stuff"
name="1_stuff"
name=" stuff"
name="st(u)ff"
name="st*(^%$#@"
```
We could specify a regex which corresponds to a valid fortran name and raise an exception if the label does not conform to this rule. Something like ...
`[a-zA-Z][a-zA-Z_]*`
but we can look at the standard and/or the parser implementations to get the appropriate regex.

Alternatively we might want to translate any unsupported characters to supported characters. This is ultimately a decision for the users.

title: named invokes should have a case insensitive match
body:
As reported by Chris Maynard ... Upper case and lower case are treated as being different when looking for matching strings. The check should be case independent to fit in with the fact that Fortran is case independent.

```
module alg
  use field_mod, only: field_type
  implicit none
  subroutine mini_alg
    implicit none
    type(field_type) :: f1, f2, f3
    call invoke( name = "X_times_Y", &
                 X_times_Y(f1, f2, f3)  &
                  )
    call invoke( name = "x_times_y", &
                 X_times_Y(f2, f3, f1)  &
                  )
  end subroutine mini_alg
end module alg
```

If he runs PSyclone over this, it generates the same routine twice with the same name

title: Parse error has missing information for named invokes
body:
As reported by Chris Maynard ... In the following example, PSyclone raises an exception but does not include the name in the exception text ...

```
module alg
  use field_mod, only: field_type
  implicit none
  subroutine mini_alg
    implicit none
    type(field_type) :: f1, f2, f3
    call invoke( name = "x_times_y", &
                 X_times_Y(f1, f2, f3)  &
                  )
    call invoke( name = "x_times_y", &
                 X_times_Y(f2, f3, f1)  &
                  )
  end subroutine mini_alg
end module alg
```

When he runs PSyclone over this it says …

 `Parse Error: Found multiple named invoke()'s with the same name: ""`

He would like the actual name, the line number and the file name.

title: builtins do not allow arguments with loop indexing
body: It has been reported that arguments to builtins which have an index e.g. a(k) cause the parser to fail. This should not be the case as kernel arguments support this feature. It therefore sounds like there is a bug somewhere. This issue is raised to check what the problem is and to fix it.

title: Correct documentation to refer to github rather than svn
body: The getting-going and system-specific set-up sections of the documentation both still talk about getting PSyclone from the Met Office SRS repository using subversion. This needs to be updated to talk about github instead.
